title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: addition loading inspecting hVCF data, rPHG2 provides classes quick loading granular visualization “PHG metrics” data. Currently, two primary types PHG metrics: used collinearity plotting samples reference genome general statistics gVCFs generated sample ×\times chromosome pair provide “easy use” downstream plotting methods, need construct new rPHG2 PHGMetrics object providing either file paths, directory paths, combination two character vector. following example, provide path directory containing alignment gVCF data found within library: variable, can simply pass PHGMetrics constructor, PHGMetrics():
code: metricDir <- system.file("extdata", package = "rPHG2")  metricDir ## [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/rPHG2/extdata" metData <- PHGMetrics(metricDir) ##  ✔ reading data for: toy_gvcf_metrics.tsv ##  ✔ reading data for: toy_anchors_s01.anchorspro metData ## A PHGMetrics object containing 2 tables: ## -- AnchorWave data: ##  ❯ toy_anchors_s01 (969 10) ## -- gVCF data: ##  ❯ toy_gvcf_metrics (41 19)

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: previously created metData object, can directly access various types data series accessor methods. want extract metrics tables data.frame-like objects, can use metricsTable() function, return list object data.frame tables:

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: want extract just one table, can provide name table metricsTable() function specifying valid name name parameter. default, PHGMetrics() constructor specify names table extracting base name file passed constructor. example, following file path: /path///alignment_file.anchorspro …default name table alignment_file. Depending complexity file ID, rPHG2 provides $ operator override allows users cycle valid metrics table names:

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: can also extract tables type using type parameter metricsTable() function. Currently, two metric types PHGv2 provides follows: align - AnchorWave alignment files gvcf - gVCF metrics files
code: metData |> metricsTable(type = "gvcf") ## # A tibble: 41 × 19 ##    taxa  chrom ref_length num_snps num_ins num_del  num_ns num_bases_inserted ##    <chr> <chr>      <int>    <int>   <int>   <int>   <int>              <int> ##  1 Xb01  ALL    473519425  2706357  336754  301867 2101168           41462213 ##  2 Xb01  Vu01    42129361   154059   26280   20211  181091            2600647 ##  3 Xb01  Vu02    33908088   178101   21457   18981  152494            2293028 ##  4 Xb01  Vu03    65292630   273800   43347   38073  284407            2694624 ##  5 Xb01  Vu04    42731077   424488   34561   31514  177567            3908337 ##  6 Xb01  Vu05    48746289   183067   28355   24918  224956            4352143 ##  7 Xb01  Vu06    34463471   149413   22663   20431  152644            2262451 ##  8 Xb01  Vu07    40876636   164945   26583   23708  178058            1966857 ##  9 Xb01  Vu08    38363498   191440   26010   24047  171568            2214889 ## 10 Xb01  Vu09    43933251   191892   27914   23807  187467            3967889 ## # ℹ 31 more rows ## # ℹ 11 more variables: num_bases_deleted <int>, ## #   percent_identity_with_ref <dbl>, percent_mapped_to_ref <dbl>, ## #   mean_insertion_size <dbl>, median_insertion_size <dbl>, ## #   largest_insertion <int>, mean_deletion_size <dbl>, ## #   median_deletion_size <dbl>, largest_deletion <int>, ## #   ref_ranges_with_haplotype <int>, haplotypes_identical_to_ref <int>

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: addition extracting tables, can also access types data found PHGMetrics objects.

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: want return IDs every table can use metricsIds() function: Similar previous section, can also return IDs metric type using type parameter:
code: metData |> metricsIds() ## [1] "toy_anchors_s01"  "toy_gvcf_metrics" metData |> metricsIds(type = "align") ## [1] "toy_anchors_s01"

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: can also extract metadata provide simple data.frame table containing three columns: file - file ID loaded data type - metrics data type id - “name” metrics table
code: metData |> metricsMetaData() ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   file                       type  id               ##   <chr>                      <chr> <chr>            ## 1 toy_gvcf_metrics.tsv       gvcf  toy_gvcf_metrics ## 2 toy_anchors_s01.anchorspro align toy_anchors_s01

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: update existing PHGMetrics can use f()<- complements accessor methods prior sections. Currently, can update add following information: metrics table names/IDs (update) metrics tables (add)

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: update pre-existing names tables object, can use metricsIds() function conjunction assignment (<-) operator passing named character vector, name vector name old table ID element new name: wish remember old IDs tables, can use prior $ operator conjunction rPHG2’s defined “” operator, %T% vector: prior code internally evaluate named character vector: can passed metricsIds() function:
code: nameMap <- c(     "old_id1" = "new_id1",     "old_id2" = "new_id2" ) nameMap <- c(     metData$toy_gvcf_metrics %T% "new_gvcf_id",     metData$toy_anchors_s01 %T% "new_anchor_id" ) nameMap ## toy_gvcf_metrics  toy_anchors_s01  ##    "new_gvcf_id"  "new_anchor_id" metricsIds(metData) <- nameMap  metData |> metricsIds() ## [1] "new_anchor_id" "new_gvcf_id"

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: update pre-existing chromosome IDs found within PHGMetrics object, can use seqnames() conjunction assignment (<-) operator passing data.frame object contains two columns: old_id - old chromosome IDs already present object new_id - new name ID can also use function return global chromosome IDs object: update, simply pass data.frame object old new ID maps seqnames() function: can see, instances "Vu01" "Vu03" globally changed "CHR_01" "CHR_03".
code: # Make copy for example purposes metNew <- metData  metNew |> seqnames() ##  [1] "1"          "2"          "3"          "Vu01"       "Vu02"       ##  [6] "Vu03"       "Vu04"       "Vu05"       "Vu06"       "Vu07"       ## [11] "Vu08"       "Vu09"       "Vu10"       "Vu11"       "contig_206" ## [16] "contig_178" keyFile <- data.frame(     old_id = c("Vu01", "Vu03"),     new_id = c("CHR_01", "CHR_03") )  seqnames(metNew) <- keyFile  metNew |> seqnames() ##  [1] "1"          "2"          "3"          "CHR_01"     "Vu02"       ##  [6] "CHR_03"     "Vu04"       "Vu05"       "Vu06"       "Vu07"       ## [11] "Vu08"       "Vu09"       "Vu10"       "Vu11"       "contig_206" ## [16] "contig_178"

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: can also add new tables existing PHGMetrics objects using metricsTable() function passing named list object containing combination valid types: file paths directory paths -memory R data.frame objects containing valid PHGv2 metric structures example, add another table via data.frame using internal toy data found rPHG2 package:
code: algnPath <- system.file("extdata/toy_anchors_s01.anchorspro", package = "rPHG2") algnDf   <- read.table(algnPath, header = TRUE, sep = "\t")  head(algnDf) ##   refChr referenceStart referenceEnd queryChr queryStart queryEnd strand ## 1      1          52892        53561        1      22637    23277      + ## 2      1         275401       278445        1     196230   199275      + ## 3      1         665653       669559        1     456629   460535      + ## 4      1         723978       724529        1     514619   515170      + ## 5      1        1031998      1033805        1     788012   789822      + ## 6      1        1497930      1503054        1    1250572  1255668      + ##          gene blockIndex   score ## 1    OQU90574         40 0.83871 ## 2 interanchor         40      NA ## 3    KXG37092         40 1.00000 ## 4    KXG37098         40 1.00000 ## 5    EER93094         40 1.00000 ## 6    KXG37167         40 1.00000 metricsTable(metData) <- list("new_algn_table" = algnDf) ##  ✔ importing data for: new_algn_table metData |> metricsMetaData() ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   file                       type  id             ##   <chr>                      <chr> <chr>          ## 1 toy_gvcf_metrics.tsv       gvcf  new_gvcf_id    ## 2 toy_anchors_s01.anchorspro align new_anchor_id  ## 3 new_algn_table             align new_algn_table

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: satisfied metrics data loaded R, can directly visualize granular diagnostic plots using plot* family functions.

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: example, want generate dot plots alignment data, can simply pass PHGMetrics object function, plotDot(). Currently can plot one table time, must specify alignment table want visualize:  Note: plot can work alignment (type = "align") data throw error gVCF-based metrics Ids used. one AnchorWave table loaded memory, user can also specify simpler approach: Note: one table loaded, approach still work, pick first table/elemement internal list object.
code: metData |> plotDot(metData$new_anchor_id) metData |> plotDot()

title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: can also visualize gVCF data using function plotGvcf(). method provides granular means visualizing various forms metrics data found within gVCF metrics file. method takes 3 primary components: PHGMetrics object metric ID gVCF metric ID ∼\sim contig ID formula simple approach pass PHGMetrics object along specified metrics ID:  Similar alignment approach, just one table, can also pass just function, since dynamically pick table:
code: metData |> plotGvcf(metData$new_gvcf_id) metData |> plotGvcf()

previous_headings: Visualize metrics data > gVCF metrics data
title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: “granular” approaches, can specify formula (f) dictate types metrics chromosome IDs want plotted using following logic: following valid metric IDs: Due number metric IDs, several “collection” IDs also valid: Note: Collection IDs may plotted one time else error thrown. example, want plot: length reference sequence (ref_length) number deletions (num_del) …chromsomes: Vu01 Vu05 …can use following formula syntax:  can also plot cumulative category combines chromosome metrics one using keyword right-hand-side equation:  One thing may noticed formula parameter required. formula used, default equation :
code: <gvcf metric ids> ~ <contig ids> metData |> plotGvcf(f = ref_length + num_del ~ Vu01 + Vu05) metData |> plotGvcf(f = ref_length + num_del ~ ALL) CORE ~ ALL

previous_headings: Visualize metrics data > gVCF metrics data
title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: can also specify dimensions plot components using two parameters: number rows (nRow) number columns (nCol)
code: metData |> plotGvcf(f = ref_length + num_del ~ ALL, nCol = 1)

previous_headings: Visualize metrics data > gVCF metrics data
title: Load and visualize PHG metrics
text: can also modify tagging type using symbolic identifiers via tag parameter:
code: metData |> plotGvcf(f = CORE ~ ALL, tag = "i")

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: rPHG objects can created two primary sources: * local data * server connections Creating initial “connection” objects helps unify downstream reading evaluation steps PHGv2 data. next couple sections, show create either local server connnection objects.

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: Local connections local TileDB instances direct locations hVCF files local disk. create local connection, create PHGLocalCon object using following constructor function: example, create connection example local hVCF files provided rPHG2 package: LineA.h.vcf LineB.h.vcf Since full paths files differ user, can use system.file() function get full path: get full path extdata directory file, LineA.h.vcf, found rPHG2 source code. can build create collection full file paths hVCF data: Now collection hVCF files, can use PHGLocalCon() constructor function create PHGLocalCon object: , can move next section create HaplotypeGraph object interface JVM.
code: PHGLocalCon() system.file("extdata", "LineA.h.vcf", package = "rPHG2") hVcfFiles <- system.file(     "extdata",      c("LineA.h.vcf", "LineB.h.vcf"),      package = "rPHG2" ) localCon <- hVcfFiles |> PHGLocalCon()  localCon ## A PHGLocalCon connection object ##  ❯ DB URI....   : ◯ ##  ❯ hVCF Files...: ◉

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: Conversely, server locations databases served publicly available web services leveraging Breeding API (BrAPI) endpoints. Since connection server, URL path instead local file path needed. use PHGServerCon() constructor function create PHGServerCon object: example, made assumptions URL: Uses secure transfer protocol (https) Uses default ports data serving BrAPI specified endpoints points 1 2, URL uses non-secure protocols (“http”) /modified port number, need specify protocol port parameters constructor function. example: point 3, constructor resolve mandatory endpoints, exception occur.
code: srvCon <- "phg.maizegdb.org" |> PHGServerCon()  srvCon ## A PHGServerCon connection object ##  ❯ Host............: phg.maizegdb.org ##  ❯ Server Status...: 200 (OK) "www.my-unsecure-phg.org" |>      PHGServerCon(         port     = 5300,          protocol = "http"     )

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: Now either local server-based connection object, can convert raw hVCF data HaplotypeGraph JVM object bridge Java reference pointer R using function, buildHaplotypeGraph(): example, took local connection object passed HaplotypeGraph constructor. , basic class contains pointer object can direct data Java R:
code: graph <- localCon |> buildHaplotypeGraph()  graph ## A HaplotypeGraph object @ 3e78b6a5 ##  ❯ # of ref ranges....: 38 ##  ❯ # of taxa..........: 2 ##  ❯ # of chromosomes...: 2 graph |> javaRefObj() ## [1] "Java-Object{net.maizegenetics.phgv2.api.HaplotypeGraph@3e78b6a5}"

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: Now created HaplotypeGraph object, can begin reading data using read* family rPHG2 functions.

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: return vector sample IDs graph object, can use readSamples() function:
code: graph |> readSamples() ## [1] "LineA" "LineB"

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: return information reference ranges found within graph object, can use readRefRanges() function. return GRanges object common data class GenomicRanges package:

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: return haplotype IDs “sample ×\times reference range” matrix object, can use readHapIds() function:

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: return metadata haplotype ID tibble object, can use readHapIdMetaData() function:
code: graph |> readHapIdMetaData() ## # A tibble: 76 × 6 ##    hap_id                 sample_name description source checksum ref_range_hash ##    <chr>                  <chr>       <chr>       <chr>  <chr>    <chr>          ##  1 0eb9029f3896313aebc69… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      39f96726321b3… ##  2 12f0cec9102e84a161866… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      546d1839623a5… ##  3 13417ecbb38b9a159e3ca… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      5812acb1aff74… ##  4 18498579d89483ac270e8… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      e07d04d2fc96b… ##  5 184a72815a2ba5949635c… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      cb86faf105b19… ##  6 1b568197f6f329ec5b71f… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      d896e9cc56e74… ##  7 1e38bd82670c3f10982f7… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      db22dfc14799b… ##  8 3149b3144f93134eb2966… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      57705b1e2541c… ##  9 369464a8743d2e40ad83d… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      66465399052d8… ## 10 3ec680649615da0685b8c… LineA       haplotype … /User… Md5      347f0478b1a55… ## # ℹ 66 more rows

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: return positional information haplotype ID another tibble object, can use readHapIdPosMetaData() function:

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: majority cases, may need one piece hVCF data. can read prior data simultaneously PHGDataSet object -R-memory representation hVCF data: object created, can use prior read* methods instantaneously pull previously mentioned R data objects: readSamples() readRefRanges() readHapIds() readHapIdMetaData() readHapIdPosMetaData()
code: graph |> readPhgDataSet() ## A PHGDataSet object ##  ❯ # of ref ranges....: 38 ##  ❯ # of samples.......: 2 ## --- ##  ❯ # of hap IDs.......: 76 ##  ❯ # of asm regions...: 76

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: cases, may want query information focus one specific reference range /sample(s). can filter PHGDataSet objects using filter* family functions. following examples, let’s picture primary data 2-dimensional matrix : samples (rows) reference ranges (columns) hap ID data (elements) represent object R called phgDs, look like following diagram:
code: phgDs

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: want filter based sample ID, can use filterSamples() function. Simply add sample ID collection sample IDs character string vector character strings, respectively. Using prior diagram reference, filter anything following: B73 Ky21 Mo17  Note: samples added filter collection, present data, discarded. samples found, exception thrown stating samples found.
code: phgDs |> filterSamples(c("B73", "Ky21", "Mo17"))

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: want filter based sample ID, can use filterRefRanges() function. Currently, takes GRanges object can specify integer-based ranges located genomic regions chromosome (.e., seqnames). example, want return ranges intersect following genomic regions: can create following GRanges object pass filter method:
code: gr <- GRanges(     seqnames = c("1", "2"),     ranges = IRanges(         c(100, 800),         c(400, 900)     ) )   phgDs |> filterRefRanges(gr)

title: Introduction to rPHG2
text: Since two dimensions, can filter simultaneously “piping” combining filter methods one pass:
code: gr <- GRanges(     seqnames = c("1", "2"),     ranges = IRanges(         c(100, 800),         c(400, 900)     ) )  phgDs |>      filterSamples(c("B73", "Ky21", "Mo17")) |>      filterRefRanges(gr)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Brandon Monier. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Monier B (2024). rPHG2: R interface PHGv2. R package version 0.5, https://rphg2.maizegenetics.net/, https://github.com/maize-genetics/rPHG2.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rPHG2: R interface to PHGv2},   author = {Brandon Monier},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.5,     https://rphg2.maizegenetics.net/},   url = {https://github.com/maize-genetics/rPHG2}, }

title: R interface to PHGv2
text: rPHG2 system interact retrieve information version 2 Practical Haplotype Graph (PHGv2) - general, graph-based, computational framework genotype inference. accomplished leveraging Breeding PHG APIs.

title: R interface to PHGv2
text: can install development version rphg2 GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("maize-genetics/rPHG2")

title: R interface to PHGv2
code: # Initialize with PHGv2 JARs initPhg("my/phg/jar/path")   # Create a connection locCon <- list.files("my/hvcf/dir") |>     PHGLocalCon()   # Build a graph graph <- locCon |> buildHaplotypeGraph()   # Read data into R phgDs <- graph |> readPhgDataSet()   # Identify areas of interest gr <- GRanges(     seqnames = c("1", "2"),     ranges = IRanges(         c(100, 800),         c(400, 900)     ) )  phgDs |>      filterSamples(c("B73", "Ky21", "Mo17")) |>      filterRefRanges(gr)

title: R interface to PHGv2
text: rPHG2 relatively new R package may subject changes workflow function definitions. like see anything added run problems, please feel free contact team using issues page.

title: R interface to PHGv2
text: installed locally, can read “Introduction rPHG2” vignette using: Alternatively, package’s website another great place read function usage, code changes, workflows.
code: vignette("rPHG2")

what: User-defined function for pre-evaluated names in vectors — %T%
title: User-defined function for pre-evaluated names in vectors — %T%
text: Generates named element. Can used conjunction c() create collection named elements

title: User-defined function for pre-evaluated names in vectors — %T%
code: lhs %T% rhs

title: User-defined function for pre-evaluated names in vectors — %T%
text: lhs Name element vector. Can either static string object need evaluated. rhs Element vector

title: User-defined function for pre-evaluated names in vectors — %T%
text: named vector

title: User-defined function for pre-evaluated names in vectors — %T%
code: # Creating a named vector with a static name vectorElement <- "value" %T% 5 print(vectorElement) #> value  #>     5   # Creating a combined named vector with both static and dynamic names nameForElement <- "dynamicName" combinedVector <- c("staticName" %T% 123, nameForElement %T% 456) print(combinedVector) #>  staticName dynamicName  #>         123         456   # Note: `%T%` can be especially useful in data manipulation where dynamic # naming of elements is required. Here's a more complex example: keyMap <- data.frame(key = "key_01") dynamicVector <- keyMap$key %T% 10 print(dynamicVector) #> key_01  #>     10

title: Generate dot plots — plotDot
text: object rPHG2 metrics object ... Additional arguments, use specific methods metricId valid metric ID character name. querySeqId Vector sequence IDs (query). refSeqId Vector sequence IDs (reference). queryLab Optional label query axis. refLab Optional label reference axis. colorId color plots (strand score)

title: Set Sequence Names for PHGMetrics Object — seqnames<-,PHGMetrics-method
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   newIds <- data.frame(     old_id = c("old_1", "old_2", "old_3"),     new_id = c("new_01", "new_02", "new_03")   )    # Assume 'met' is a PHGMetrics object   seqnames(met) <- newIds } # }

title: rPHG2 0.3
text: memory representation hVCF data sets Filters relevant rPHG2 data objects reference range Requires GRanges object input Filters relevant rPHG2 data objects sample ID Input basic character vector sample identifiers

title: rPHG2 0.2
text: Added JVM connections via rJava interface Wrapper PHGv2 API Java graph object Interface local hVCF database file connections Initializes JVM adds PHGv2 Java JARs classpath Reads haplotype IDs character matrix connection object Reads ALT header metadata haplotype ID connection object Reads ALT header positional metadata haplotype ID connection object Reads sample IDs connection object Read reference range positional information GRanges object connection object
